name: Falconer's conjecture
summary: Falconer's conjecture is an unsolved problem in geometric measure theory that states that a compact set of points in \(d\)-dimensional Euclidean space with a Hausdorff dimension greater than \(d/2\) must have a distance set of strictly positive Lebesgue measure. Intuitively, the conjecture suggests that a sufficiently "large" or "dense" set of points will determine a set of distances that is also "large" and not just a few isolated values. The conjecture is considered a continuous analogue of the Erdős distance problem for finite sets of points.
head: If \(E\) is a compact subset of \(\mathbb{R}^{d}\) (where \(d\ge 2\)) with Hausdorff dimension strictly greater than \(d/2\)
tail: then its distance set \(\Delta (E)=\{|x-y|:x,y\in E\}\) has positive one-dimensional Lebesgue measure.
